Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Signal Amplification by Cation Exchange in Ionic Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Wenwan Zhong of the University of California-Riverside is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to develop a novel signal amplification approach for biochemical sensing based on cation exchange in ionic nanocrystals (CXAmp). The specific goals are: 1) to explore the kinetics and equilibria of cation exchange in nanocrystals; 2) to maximize the signal enhancement factor of cation exchange amplification; and 3) to apply this novel sensing methodology for the detection of viral particles in human serum. A problem-based learning approach will be established in the upper division undergraduate chemistry course "Instrumental Methods Laboratory." A chemical education programs at the Riverside Public library will be initiated using educational material available on the ACS web site.

Functional biomolecules in biological and biomedical samples are often present at trace concentration levels. This project promises to lead to a highly sensitive signaling strategy for the sensing and the analysis of trace amounts of such biomolecules. The project will also provide new knowledge about the reactivity and stability of nanocrystals in biological systems and the environment, thus enhancing their applications in biomedical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
intellectual merit

The major accomplishments from this NSF grant include: 1) Development of new nanomaterials to be used in bioassays and their applications in protein and microRNA detection; 2) Combination of nanomaterials and separation techniques for improved understanding of bioconjugation, in molecular detection, and in analyte extraction; and 3) Investigation of new methods to speed up biomarker discovery. New sensing strategies developed include isothermal amplification assays, target-responsive reagents for cellular imaging, and high-throughput screening techniques for studying the nano-bio interface. With the support from NSF, we also developed a new platform for identification of circulating miRNA markers, and a new method for search of new aptamers for biomarkers, which will be useful tools for the group’s future work in the area of molecular detection. The award also helped to establish new collaborations on the development of supramolecular receptor-based sensors for protein modification. Moreover, under the support of a supplement to this grant issued in 2014, the Zhong group established international collaborations to further expand its capability in sensor development.

broader of impacts

The work has led to the publication of more than 17 papers and 2 patent applications being filed. The PI also attended numerous conferences and gave talks to disseminate the impact of their works. With the enabling technologies developed under the support of this grant, we hope to improve the efficacy of biomarker discovery and detection, and help us defend ourselves against diseases better. Our work has also provided multidisciplinary training opportunities to graduate students and undergraduate students. Some of them join the work force of industry and some continue to work in academic institutions. They will be the future strength in chemistry work force and contribute to move the field forward in the near future.
